messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] papering tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Should anybody be interested I have one copy of this in stock, see below: Alan MATSUMIYA. Tsuba Shokan Kuketsu - Tsuba Kenkyu no Tebiki to Kansho. A
messages.messageBody:
Should anybody be interested I have one copy of this in stock, see below:
Alan


MATSUMIYA. Tsuba Shokan Kuketsu - Tsuba Kenkyu no Tebiki to Kansho. A
Reproduction of the 18th Century Manuscript Tsuba Zufu. 1967. 7.25"x10.25"
slip case, 210pp of which 158pp are plates illustrating 317 tsuba by
drawings, plus 29pp of comments by Kawaguchi, Torigoe, Wakayama and other
experts. An important early work on the study of tsuba. GBP65

----- Original Message -----

Estimated

> monograph on the appreciation of the tsuba. The hand-written original has
> long been lost, but over the years numerous hand-copies were made among
> tsuba and sword enthusiasts. Since the extant copies were becoming scarce
> and out of reach of average tsuba enthusiasts, Shibata Mitsuo undertook
the
> project of publishing the book in a modern format in 1967. This book is
the
> result of that effort. Original text and illustrations (taken from several
> reliable copies in existence) are duplicated in large pages, and modern
> typesetting was added to enable today's audience to read the cursive
> classical writing. The direct translation of the title is "Orally
> transmitted secret of the appreciation of the tsuba," but "How to
Appreciate

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] papering tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks, Darcy.  I tend to like old iron mumei examples, and I only got interested in tsuba recently, so I don t own the kind Sasano did.  Maybe I should get a
messages.messageBody:
Thanks, Darcy. I tend to like old iron mumei examples, and I only got interested in tsuba recently, so I don't own the kind Sasano did. Maybe I should get a sword polished, and try papering it.



----- Original Message -----
From: samurai@...
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, March 20, 2005 4:34 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] papering tsuba



Hi David,

I have not submitted many (any) tsuba, but was faced with the same
dilemma.

I would think:

1. if there is a possibility that it is old and rare vs. the more common
pieces and you want to assure yourself or a buyer of this

2. it has a big name and you want assurance it is legit

3. it's going to paper high

Otherwise, papers cover a substantial portion of the price of a tsuba if
papered... I'd say generally avoid it as not being fiscally sound.

That said I think the NTHK has much better prices on papering tsuba that
make more sense than the NBTHK. I was considering NTHK papers for mine.

- darcy

<jdz@...> writes:

> I've never submitted anything for papers, and just to experience the process I was thinking of submitting one or two tsuba to shinsa.

> But looking at the costs, and not believing I own any more than Hozon-level sorts of tsuba, I began to wonder if it made sense to spend several hundred dollars just to add minimum Hozon papers, or perhaps to fail.

> Any wisdom out there on how good a tsuba needs to be to be Hozon or Tokubetsu Hozon? Why paper a tsuba at all? What makes you decide to submit a particular one?

> DZ

> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] papering tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi: Thank you for that really interesting reference. I must do all this from my head and in the back was some recollection of something done in mid-Edo times,
messages.messageBody:
Hi:
Thank you for that really interesting reference. I must do all this
from my head and in the back was some recollection of something done in
mid-Edo times, but I couldn't remember the title and that may be it. I
think the underlying point though is that systematic study is really
very new and I believe most retrospectives of the literature would place
the practical origin with Akiyama. It is that newness that makes all
opinions somewhat uncertain by either the category or time dimension, or
both. There are unresolved and unstable areas with respect to swords
too, but they are more in the way of skirmishes, rather than battles.
Thanks again for the useful information.
Arnold


>>> "David Zincavage" <jdz@...> 03/21/05 1:00 PM >>>
Thanks, Arnold. Not too long ago, I came across a reprint of a tsuba
book
written in 1736. I can even supply a picture, because I put photos
whenever
possible of Japanese language titles into my bibliography, which I need
to
avoid duplicate acquisitions. Koshoyama found me a copy.

Kanzan, Matsumiya. Tsuba shokan koketsu, 7.5" x 10.5", 210 pages.
Estimated
to be authored in 1736, "Tsuba shokan koketsu" is said to be the oldest
monograph on the appreciation of the tsuba. The hand-written original
has
long been lost, but over the years numerous hand-copies were made among
tsuba and sword enthusiasts. Since the extant copies were becoming
scarce
and out of reach of average tsuba enthusiasts, Shibata Mitsuo undertook
the
project of publishing the book in a modern format in 1967. This book is
the
result of that effort. Original text and illustrations (taken from
several
reliable copies in existence) are duplicated in large pages, and modern
typesetting was added to enable today's audience to read the cursive
classical writing. The direct translation of the title is "Orally
transmitted secret of the appreciation of the tsuba," but "How to
Appreciate
the Tsuba" would be much more appropriate for the content.

> the date of the adoption and substantial spread of the use of
> uchi-gatana. All one needs to do is to watch the moving time line in
the
> writings of the late Sasano Masayuki.
> My advice would be to be conservative in what you submit unless it is
a
> piece about which you have a great deal of curiosity and it being of
> good workmanship, preservation and aesthetic content. On the other
hand
> one can not sell short the impact that papers have on the value of
> fittings and the certainty with which they can be sold at a
predictable
> price, if that is of relevance to you.
> Arnold
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] papering tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks, Arnold.  Not too long ago, I came across a reprint of a tsuba book written in 1736.  I can even supply a picture, because I put photos whenever
messages.messageBody:
Thanks, Arnold. Not too long ago, I came across a reprint of a tsuba book
written in 1736. I can even supply a picture, because I put photos whenever
possible of Japanese language titles into my bibliography, which I need to
avoid duplicate acquisitions. Koshoyama found me a copy.

Kanzan, Matsumiya. Tsuba shokan koketsu, 7.5" x 10.5", 210 pages. Estimated
to be authored in 1736, "Tsuba shokan koketsu" is said to be the oldest
monograph on the appreciation of the tsuba. The hand-written original has
long been lost, but over the years numerous hand-copies were made among
tsuba and sword enthusiasts. Since the extant copies were becoming scarce
and out of reach of average tsuba enthusiasts, Shibata Mitsuo undertook the
project of publishing the book in a modern format in 1967. This book is the
result of that effort. Original text and illustrations (taken from several
reliable copies in existence) are duplicated in large pages, and modern
typesetting was added to enable today's audience to read the cursive
classical writing. The direct translation of the title is "Orally
transmitted secret of the appreciation of the tsuba," but "How to Appreciate
the Tsuba" would be much more appropriate for the content.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] papering tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi: That is any excellent set of questions. It is useful to remember that while sword knowledge and what should be designated as what goes back at least to the
messages.messageBody:
Hi:
That is any excellent set of questions. It is useful to remember that
while sword knowledge and what should be designated as what goes back at
least to the time of the first Ashikaga Shogun, knowledge of tosogu,
particularly iron tsuba, goes back no early than the late Bakumatsu era,
particularly with the writings of Akiyama and
Kawaguchi. The knowledge paradigm is a still expanding one and the
boundaries are somewhat indistinct and evolving. There can be a great
deal of controversy as to what group something falls into and wildly
different opinions as to age of manufacture, that of course hinging on
the date of the adoption and substantial spread of the use of
uchi-gatana. All one needs to do is to watch the moving time line in the
writings of the late Sasano Masayuki.
My advice would be to be conservative in what you submit unless it is a
piece about which you have a great deal of curiosity and it being of
good workmanship, preservation and aesthetic content. On the other hand
one can not sell short the impact that papers have on the value of
fittings and the certainty with which they can be sold at a predictable
price, if that is of relevance to you.
Arnold












>>> jdz@... 03/20/05 3:17 PM >>>

I've never submitted anything for papers, and just to experience the
process I was thinking of submitting one or two tsuba to shinsa.

But looking at the costs, and not believing I own any more than
Hozon-level sorts of tsuba, I began to wonder if it made sense to spend
several hundred dollars just to add minimum Hozon papers, or perhaps to
fail.

Any wisdom out there on how good a tsuba needs to be to be Hozon or
Tokubetsu Hozon? Why paper a tsuba at all? What makes you decide to
submit a particular one?

DZ

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]





Yahoo! Groups Links

3. it's going to paper high

Otherwise, papers cover a substantial portion of the price of a tsuba if

That said I think the NTHK has much better prices on papering tsuba that
make more sense than the NBTHK. I was considering NTHK papers for mine.

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: papering tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 7/10/2003 2:16:05 PM Central Daylight Time, ... gang, an alternative to sending to NBTHK shinsa ( postage/insurance, agent s fee, shinsa fee
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 7/10/2003 2:16:05 PM Central Daylight Time,
swords@... writes:

> Ken, Rich -
>
> This seems to be the situation today with the doubling of NBTHK shinsa costs
> a year or so ago. Today, I would only submit a tsuba to shinsa if the
> signature was important enough to make the tsuba "valuable" enough to justify the
> costs. One tsuba here that I'm considering sending to shinsa is mumei but if
> judged "Akasaka" and perhaps designated to a particular generation, in my
> eyes, it would justify the cost of shinsa. Bob Benson mentioned awhile back that
> a lot of people are acquiring only Hozon papers and not bothering with paying
> for Tokubetsu shinsa, simply to "confirm" the mei.
>
> Personally, I am an advocate of papers being gotten on "priority" items in
> my collection.
>
> Ron
> STL
>

gang,
an alternative to sending to NBTHK shinsa ( postage/insurance, agent's fee,
shinsa fee etc could run to 400 just for hozon paper) is to wait for the NTHK
shinsa in LA 2004.

Milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: papering tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Ken, Rich - This seems to be the situation today with the doubling of NBTHK shinsa costs a year or so ago. Today, I would only submit a tsuba to shinsa if the
messages.messageBody:
Ken, Rich -

This seems to be the situation today with the doubling of NBTHK shinsa costs a year or so ago. Today, I would only submit a tsuba to shinsa if the signature was important enough to make the tsuba "valuable" enough to justify the costs. One tsuba here that I'm considering sending to shinsa is mumei but if judged "Akasaka" and perhaps designated to a particular generation, in my eyes, it would justify the cost of shinsa. Bob Benson mentioned awhile back that a lot of people are acquiring only Hozon papers and not bothering with paying for Tokubetsu shinsa, simply to "confirm" the mei.

Personally, I am an advocate of papers being gotten on "priority" items in my collection.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: alchemyst
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, July 10, 2003 12:24 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: papering tsuba


Ken -

My feeble thoughts on the topic. I have several papered
tsuba; all purchased with papers. Papers aren't my thing.
But I do plan on submitting two or three at the next US
shinsa just to get opinions on school and age. IMHO
unless it is a matter of verifying a mei of a famous
maker; getting info is the main reason for submitting for
papers. I agree that at the current rates, especially for
the NBTHK, it is not feasible to submit anything but very
high grade fittings. The cost of the shinsa is more than
the fittings (even with papers) would be worth in most cases.
Just my humble $0.03 worth (to allow for inflation)

Rich

messages.subject: papering tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I have privately shared the 2 tsuba that spawned my Mito questions with Jim and Cary.  Cary suggested it would be best to submit these in Japan and it
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

I have privately shared the 2 tsuba that spawned my
Mito questions with Jim and Cary. Cary suggested it
would be best to submit these in Japan and it got me
thinking about many questions surrounding this
process. I don't recall a lot of discussion around
fittings submission, but there have been many
discussions on submiting swords. So I thought it would
be helpful (for at least some of us or at least me).
1. When is it worth submitting fittings to shinsa? I
understand the value of knowledge but aren't fees a
little high for fittings in relation to swords?
2. Is the process similiar to swords, must submit
several times for higher papers?
2. What criteria would you use? for example, price: a
$250 tsuba may not but a $500 would? or age a late edo
piece isn't worth it?
3. A sword with papers usually increases value (often
greatly(?)). How much would this apply to tsuba
and/or fittings in general?
4. What kind of conditions must your tsuba be in for a
real consideration? patina, rust, missing inlay, etc?
5. Does age factor into condition, ie koto swords may
have certain flaws overlooked in the papering process
but shinto would not, does this translate over to
tsuba?

All comments are appreciated. By the way, the 2 tsuba
I was questioning are located in the other yahoo list
folder under mantis (I think labeled "11 &1") which
were recently shared with on that list. Anyone else
interested I will gladly send pics of.

Thank you
Ken



__________________________________
Do you Yahoo!?
SBC Yahoo! DSL - Now only $29.95 per month!
http://sbc.yahoo.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba value ?
messages.msgSnippet: Some of the smallest daito tsuba that I am aware of are found on a few of the well-known Tensho period katana koshirae. For the earlier question about katana
messages.messageBody:
Some of the smallest daito tsuba that I am aware of are found on a few of the well-known Tensho period katana koshirae.

For the earlier question about katana vs. wakizashi tsuba sizes see the "Katana Koshirae" .xls or .doc files on the group site:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/files/

Jim



With number four Matt I think you are closest to the truth,
A large tsuba is a hindrance for a mounted archer, encounters
on horseback were rarely "tsuba to tsuba" therefore a handgaurd if it
ever was one was unnecessary. A handstop on the other hand was of
absolute necessity...
-t


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba value ?
messages.msgSnippet: I agree with Arnold in theory, however my experience in practice is that larger guards (although not ones grotesquely so) tend to be more sought after.  I ve
messages.messageBody:
I agree with Arnold in theory, however my experience in practice is that larger guards (although not ones grotesquely so) tend to be more sought after. I've found that both in Japan and the US. It is certainly a multi-variable issue, though.

How and why tsuba sizes vary over time is a very interesting and complex question.

Jim



While I agree with Arnold's points, I would suspect
that given two tsuba of equal quality the larger would
likely bring bigger bucks. Just the Western hangup
that bigger is better.

As for why smaller on some earlier tsuba, I suspect just
a matter of style of the period. A tsuba should (?) balance
a blade somewhat (although the effect may be only slight
if at all), so as blade shapes, lengths and weights changed,
so would tsuba size. Just my uneducated opinion on the topic.

Rich

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba value ?
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, There were Shoami documented working in many more locations than that.  Again, check page 246 of the Tsuba Taikan for Shoami working in Mito.  I haven t
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
There were Shoami documented working in many more locations than that. Again, check page 246 of the Tsuba Taikan for Shoami working in Mito. I haven't tried to slog through a translation yet. Cary mentioned off line that he was having serious computer problems, so be patient.

Jim


Ken,
Mito" I might not exist " Shoami only adds to the confusion.
A quick glancing from one of those Japanese " handbook size " tsuba book that
has a map with all ( most ? ) tsuba schools shows............
1. 7 Shoami associated with different locations .
2. 1 Ko-Shoami
3. 1 Kiami ( works look just like Shoami )

p.s. Mito Shoami not included /listed

Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba value ?
messages.msgSnippet: Matt et all, I ll disagree with one of Arnold s points, this isn t a great question.  When I asked it a few months ago (less than 2 I believe), it was a great
messages.messageBody:
Matt et all,
I'll disagree with one of Arnold's points, this isn't
a great question. When I asked it a few months ago
(less than 2 I believe), it was a great question, now
it is a rehash of a topic (but I'll give you still a
relevant one). I believe Gordon's answer given was 2
comparable tsuba with all things being equal except in
different sizes, the larger one would be worth more.
So I don't know if that is western thought or not.
But I can't speak for him. I was curious at the time
because of 2 Mito/mito "I might not exist" shoami
tsuba I have, plus I knew that this statement applied
to swords.

Ken

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] tsuba value ?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Arnold, Very interesting. Was there any particular reason why the older tsuba are smaller ? I have come up with 4 ideas 1. Maybe the swords were shorter, so
messages.messageBody:
Hi Arnold,

Very interesting. Was there any particular reason why the older tsuba
are smaller ?

I have come up with 4 ideas

1. Maybe the swords were shorter, so had a smaller tsuba ? (unlikely
considering the Nambokucho monsters)

2. People had smaller hands back then, therefore requiring a smaller
tsuba ? (doubtful in my opinion)

3. The swords were better balanced at that time, think Kamakura etc,
therefore required less tsuba for balance ? (this is my favorite at the
moment together with the last one)

4. Since the swords were used on horseback with one arm, they had to be
light, ergo a small tsuba.

- Matt



-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Arnold Frenzel [mailto:afrenzel@...]
Verzonden: woensdag 9 juli 2003 23:32
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba value ?


Hi:
What an interesting question! I think that as a general rule the notion
of size and value, other things being equal, except in the restricted
situation of a daisho perfectly matched, but now separated pair, is
really
not an operational comparison. Tsuba size choices of the artisan were
determined by the parameters of the blade and koshirae appropriate to
the
period of initial manufacture. What make tsuba interesting and desirable
is how close the fit is what it ought to be for the time of manufacture.
If one follows Sasano sensei, for example, with respect to the earliest
tosho tsuba, the early ones were small and the later ones as a rule were
larger. Even though the designs might be quite similar, the criterion of
originality and probable scarcity ought to yield a significantly higher
price for the older but smaller piece. Mutatis mutandis the same
argument
holds for tsuba of different types and periods. How close the fit
between
the piece at hand and the ideal type is probably the main determinant of
value. For a short answer I do not believe that there is a correlation
merely between size and market value. My two cents worth anyway.

Arnold Frenzel
afrenzel@...


On Wed, 9 Jul 2003, Matthew E. Hoyle wrote:

> Hi gang,
>
> I was wondering how the size of a tsuba affects it's value. All things
> being equal, would a 2.8 inch diam tsuba be worth less than say an
> identical 3.5 inch one ? Or even a 4 inch one ?
>
> also when is a tsuba considered to be of wakizashi or katana size ?
and
> would that affect the price as well ?
>
> thanks for listening !
>
>
> - Matt
>
>

messages.subject: tsuba value ?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi gang, I was wondering how the size of a tsuba affects it s value. All things being equal, would a 2.8 inch diam tsuba be worth less than say an identical
messages.messageBody:
Hi gang,

I was wondering how the size of a tsuba affects it's value. All things
being equal, would a 2.8 inch diam tsuba be worth less than say an
identical 3.5 inch one ? Or even a 4 inch one ?

also when is a tsuba considered to be of wakizashi or katana size ? and
would that affect the price as well ?

thanks for listening !


- Matt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
